Title.evidence: Infrapatellar Fat Pad Excision in Minimally Invasive Total Knee Arthroplasty: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Intervention.evidence: randomised into two groups: 45 patients with complete infrapatellar fat pad excision and 45 without

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was anterior knee pain, measured at 6 weeks, 3 months, 6 months, and 1 year postoperatively

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors

Number_Randomised.evidence: 90 patients undergoing MIS TKA, randomised into two groups

Number_Analysed.evidence: Complete follow-up data were available for 77 of 90 patients (86%)

Result_Outcome.evidence: anterior knee pain was more prevalent in the excision group (8.3% versus 0%; p = 0.03; 95% CI, âˆ’0.007 to 0.174)

Harms.evidence: No patellar complications were reported in either group
